judge.brief_assessment: The generated AGENTS.md is well-structured Markdown with accurate Python/FastAPI code examples that are idiomatic and correctly use FastAPI patterns (Depends, APIRouter, Pydantic models, async handlers). It covers most of the six core areas (Project Overview, Development Guidelines, Testing, Building/Running, Common Tasks/Workflows) but the content is truncated mid-sentence in the 'Adding a New Dependency' section, meaning the sixth area (likely a section on architecture/debugging or similar) is missing. No cross-language contamination is detected; all code snippets are proper Python with correct FastAPI and pytest idioms.

This is an excellent AGENTS.md file written entirely in Markdown with no cross-language contamination. It covers all six core areas of the AGENTS.md specification: Overview/context, Build & Run instructions, Testing procedures, Project Structure (code map), Code Style conventions, Git Workflow, and Boundaries (always/ask/never). The embedded Python example code is idiomatic FastAPI with proper async patterns, Pydantic models, and dependency injection. The content is well-organized, comprehensive, and tailored accurately to the specified stack (Poetry, pytest, FastAPI, conventional commits, Makefile).

contamination_signals: Includes a bash command (`ls AGENTS.md 2>/dev/null`) as a preliminary check, which was not requested and is not markdown
Generates an unrequested CLAUDE.md file, going beyond the task scope
Nested bash code block inside the markdown file creates rendering issues with triple-backtick fencing
judge.brief_assessment: The generated AGENTS.md is well-structured and covers the key aspects of the project: build commands, directory structure, content conventions, code style, and boundaries. The markdown is idiomatic and appropriate for the task. Minor issues include: the unnecessary bash check and CLAUDE.md generation go beyond scope, the nested code fences (bash block inside markdown) could cause rendering problems in some parsers, and some conventions (dark-mode Mermaid colors, citation patterns) appear fabricated rather than derived from the provided context. Overall a solid output with minor completeness and accuracy concerns.
